issues.description: The problem statement instructs students to create a constructor that "follows the same order from the UML diagram" (problem_statement.md lines 19-21). However, the UML in the problem statement lists attributes in the order: numberOfInscribedStudents, lectureName, numberOfLecturers, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfTutors (problem_statement.md lines 63-69). The solution repository implements a constructor whose parameter order starts with lectureName, then numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors (solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Lecture.java lines 13-19). The textual attribute list earlier in the problem statement (problem_statement.md line 17) also lists lectureName first, which conflicts with the UML order. This mismatch (UML vs. textual description vs. solution) can confuse students about the expected constructor parameter order and may cause them to implement a constructor different from the reference solution or the UML.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the intended constructor parameter order consistent across all artifacts. Option A: Update the UML in the problem statement to list attributes in the same order as the textual description and the solution (lectureName first), and clarify the constructor parameter order in the instructions. Option B: If the UML order is authoritative, update the solution (and any reference tests) so the constructor parameters follow the UML order (numberOfInscribedStudents, lectureName, numberOfLecturers, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfTutors). Ensure the template's TODOs and any example usage reflect the chosen consistent order so students are not confused.
